prior_works.title: Emergent Complexity and Zero-shot Transfer via Unsupervised Environment Design (PAIRED)
prior_works.authors: Michael Dennis, Natasha Jaques, Jack Parker-Holder, et al.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduced regret as the core signal for teacher-driven environment generation in UED, establishing the regret-driven curricula that CENIE explicitly complements by quantifying environment novelty beyond difficulty/regret.

prior_works.title: POET: Paired Open-Ended Trailblazer
prior_works.authors: Rui Wang, Joel Lehman, Kenneth O. Stanley, Jeff Clune
prior_works.role: Open-ended environment generation with explicit novelty
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Demonstrated that sustained progress in open-ended RL requires explicitly seeking novel, diverse environments, directly motivating CENIE’s focus on principled environment-novelty measurement.

prior_works.title: Abandoning Objectives: Evolution Through the Search for Novelty Alone
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Established behavior-space novelty as a first-class optimization signal, inspiring CENIE’s separation of novelty from difficulty/regret and its need for a robust, task-agnostic novelty quantification.

prior_works.title: Illuminating Search Spaces by Mapping Elites (MAP-Elites)
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provided the principle of coverage across a behavior/descriptor space as a quantitative objective, which directly informs CENIE’s coverage-based evaluation of environment novelty.

prior_works.title: Automatic Goal Generation for Reinforcement Learning Agents (GoalGAN)
prior_works.authors: Carlos Florensa, David Held, Xinjie Geng, Pieter Abbeel
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Showed that curriculum quality improves when goal generation balances difficulty and novelty, motivating CENIE’s explicit modeling of environment novelty rather than relying solely on regret.

prior_works.title: Leveraging Procedural Generation to Benchmark Reinforcement Learning (Procgen Benchmark)
prior_works.authors: Nicholas Cobbe, Christopher Hesse, Jacob Hilton, John Schulman
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Highlighted the importance of diversity and unseen-environment generalization, reinforcing the need for a principled environment-novelty metric like CENIE to drive curricula that transfer.

synthesis_narrative: The paper’s key contribution—CENIE, a coverage-based evaluation of environment novelty for UED—emerges at the intersection of regret-driven curricula and open-ended diversity-driven design. PAIRED formalized UED with regret as the central curriculum signal, yielding progressively harder environments but often overlooking novelty, which this work targets explicitly. From the open-ended learning side, POET demonstrated that sustained progress and zero-shot robustness require explicitly searching for novel environments, foreshadowing the need to measure diversity independently of task performance. Foundationally, Novelty Search introduced behavior-space novelty as an objective orthogonal to reward, establishing the conceptual distinction CENIE operationalizes within UED. MAP-Elites then provided a concrete, quantitative lens on diversity—coverage across a descriptor space—directly inspiring CENIE’s coverage-based quantification that remains agnostic to underspecified environment parameters. Complementarily, GoalGAN showed that balancing difficulty with novelty produces stronger curricula, reinforcing the paper’s argument that regret alone is insufficient. Finally, Procgen crystallized the evaluation imperative: agents must generalize to unseen, procedurally generated environments, a setting where better novelty measurement should translate to performance gains. Together, these works directly shaped CENIE’s design: a principled, coverage-oriented novelty metric that augments regret to produce curricula that are not only challenging but also diverse, thereby improving generalization.
